subject: Re: [junit] Literate asserts
msgSnippet: ... The main benefit of literate programming that I gather from reading earlier messages is that it makes the error messages easier to read. Given this
messageBody:
Quoting Alexandru Popescu <the.mindstorm.mailinglist@...>:
>> How about:
>>
>> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
>>
>> and I would have thought
>>
>> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10))
>>
>> should be possible as well.
>>
>
> ... but are you sure it is more readable than:
>
> assertTrue( 2 < n && n < 10, "n should be inside the (2, 10) interval");

The main benefit of literate programming that I gather from reading
earlier messages is that it makes the error messages easier to read.
Given this example:
assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
it seems to me to be at the expense of the readability of the tests
(in some cases), and also likely at the expense of amount of effort
required to code the tests. But maybe that's a good tradeoff.

For me, the answer is that my tests don't fail often enough to warrant
that extra expense. Since I'm doing TDD, assertions generally fail
once, maybe a few times, during development. And while I'm developing,
I'm pretty familiar with what the test failures mean. But after that,
failing tests are pretty rare, and I want them to be. So, I don't
usually bother with assertion failure messages.

When assertion failures do occur, *I have to look at the test anyway.*

[ BTW, the assertion failure message shown as an example here (which
probably won't compile, since the message goes first in JUnit) doesn't
tell me what "n" is--that's more useful than a message that simply
restates the conditional expression. I'd probably code:
assertTrue("out of range: " + n, 2 < n && n < 10)
But that's nitpicking on email-code. I think I know what you probably meant. ]

Yeah, it'd be nice to have a prettier failure message. But, that's OK:
if I get a failed test and can't decipher the meaning of the failure,
I code the nicer failure message and rerun the tests. If it's the kind
of failure that keeps recurring, however unfortunately, I'll keep the
message in, otherwise I'll delete it. I might also build a custom
assert method:
assertInRange(2, n, 10);
... particularly if I have a similar need elsewhere in the code. I
probably do. And at that point an assertion failure message, created
in assertInRange, is very prudent.

Sometimes, complex assertions hint at a problem with my system's
design--there might be a need for such a construct in the system itself:

assertTrue(new productionpackage.Interval(2, 10).encloses(n));

Given all the choices, I think the Java language makes the literate
programming one the least appealing to me. It is what it is.

Jeff
